Description: A forepart fragment of a hollow terracotta horse, modelled in the round, the neck and head remaining, with details of harness in serrated relief lines. A suspension-hole is pierced through the neck. Both hands of a rider are shown, one each side of the neck, with a small hole pierced through adjacent to them. The muzzle is lost and the ears damaged. Two-piece mould. Pink Aswan kaolinite ware, covered with a pink to yellow slip. Painted lines, showing eyes and mane, and more of the harness, in black fired-on ceramic colour, with a red band down the nose and chest and on the breastband, also of ceramic colour.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Close: Ballet and Mahmoud 1987: pl. xiv:16, mould fragment from Elephantine, dated first third of seventh century AD. Near: Boutantin 2004: 8, fig. 1, from Coptos, and ibid.: 13, fig. 19, from Amarna, both dated fifth to sixth century AD; Letellier and Ziegler 1977: 28, no. 24; Michałowski et al. 1950: pl. xxx:20, from Edfu, 'Coptic' context; Mond and Myers 1940: pl. lxx:21, from Armant; Weber 1914: no. 447, from Elephantine. Bibliog: Boutantin 2004: 10, fig. 6, dated fifth to sixth century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3758)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
